page.title: 14AREA, BUILDINGS, CHITTERNE
page.content: The area is on the southern edge of Salisbury Plain. The landscape is rolling chalk downland used mainly for agriculture, dotted with clumps of trees, many of which at one time sheltered dwelling places. The village of Chitterne lies in a valley surrounded by mature trees. All that remains of the 14th century St Mary's Church is the Chancel built of stone with a tiled roof. There are two ancient barns built of wood on brick bases, and other farm buildings belonging to the brick Elizabethan Manor . The King's Head Public House is an old stone building, at one time thatched. Chitterne lies within a conservation area, and there are a number of listed buildings, and a hump backed bridge, no longer used by traffic.
